snippet: A Chinese freshman at an American public university will typically pay three times what an in-state student pays. And with increasing numbers of Chinese kids at U.S. colleges, even with a booming economy back home, how are they paying more than...
abstract: A Chinese freshman at an American public university will typically pay three times what an in-state student pays. And with increasing numbers of Chinese kids at U.S. colleges, even with a booming economy back home, how are they paying more than $50,000 a year? A high school educator from one of Beijing's leading schools explains the how, the why and the how much.
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous recently poked around the issue of Chinese high school students doctoring their applications to gain admission to U.S universities. Surveys and anecdotal evidence suggest that more than half of all Chinese students will have faked something in their admission packets.

headline.main: Chinese Students Paying U.S. Tuitions — How? And Why?
